claims.claim: Intratumoral mRNA vaccination induces a type I interferon response in tumours.

evidence.quote: Type I interferon response score (normalized units) | 3.1 | 1.0 | Marked induction after mRNA vaccination in tumors
Intratumoral mRNA vaccination triggers local innate sensing and type I interferon signaling.

claims.caveat: This report summarizes mechanistic induction primarily from tumour measurements and proposed chain; strength may vary by model system.

claims.claim: Intratumoral mRNA vaccination broadens antigen presentation, including expansion of the MHC-I peptidome.

evidence.quote: Fraction of tumor proteins represented in immunopeptidome | 62.3% | 37.3% | Broader antigen display after intratumoral mRNA vaccination
Fraction of proteins represented in MHC-I peptidome | 40.6% | 20.6% | Strong expansion of MHC-I-presented landscape
A broader peptide repertoire appears on MHC-I, improving tumor visibility to T cells.

claims.caveat: These quantitative peptidome fractions are reported as preclinical readouts and may not directly translate to clinical tumour antigen presentation breadth.

claims.claim: The combined strategy (intratumoral mRNA vaccination plus anti-PD-L1) improves tumour control in mice and is consistent with improved outcomes in a retrospective human cohort.

evidence.quote: Preclinical arm: multiple murine tumor models with intratumoral mRNA vaccine and anti-PD-L1 combinations.
Combined intervention improves tumor control in mice and aligns with better outcomes in the retrospective human cohort.
Retrospective human survival comparison p-value | p=0.01 | N/A | Vaccinated subgroup had improved survival under ICI treatment

claims.caveat: The human evidence is explicitly retrospective and non-randomized, so the alignment with better outcomes cannot establish causality for vaccination improving ICI response.

claims.claim: The sensitization benefit depends on type I interferon signaling, because IFNAR1 blockade eliminates the effect.

evidence.quote: Blocking type I interferon signaling with anti-IFNAR1 eliminated the observed sensitization benefit.
Interferon-associated antigen processing and presentation pathways increase.

claims.caveat: Elimination of benefit with IFNAR1 blockade is a mechanistic control within the tested models; it does not prove the same dependency in all tumour types or in patients.

claims.claim: The retrospective human comparison is vulnerable to confounding and is not sufficient for direct causal interpretation.

evidence.quote: The human analysis is retrospective and non-randomized; residual confounding is likely.
Tumor-type mix and treatment-history heterogeneity limit direct causal interpretation.

claims.caveat: Despite these limitations, the analysis may still be hypothesis-generating for prospective trial design rather than definitive evidence of benefit.
